Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A social media post about your cause is currently going viral, and now is the perfect moment to add a comment with more information.
Story: I stood in the living room, my stepmother’s voice echoing as she handed me the ceremonial candle. “It’s your turn to lead this year, to show you’re truly part of our family.” Her eyes were hopeful, and I felt the weight of her trust. At the same time, my phone buzzed relentlessly in my pocket. My activist group’s post about climate justice was exploding online—thousands of people were watching, waiting for more information, and I knew my comment could make a real difference. My stepmother’s expectation pressed on me: honor the family, respect tradition, prove I belong. But my activist side screamed that this was the moment to educate, to seize the momentum for change. My hands trembled, torn between the warmth of family acceptance and the urgent call to action. I could feel both worlds pulling at me, each demanding all of me, and I stood frozen, heart pounding, unable to choose.
